ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Deeper understanding of bonding in coordination complexes, symmetry, spin & magnetism, redox-active ligands, chelating ligands, and ligand design than I had received in past courses, but still a somewhat shallow depth of knowledge on each individual topic just due to the half-term nature of the course... I think that this would make an excellent full-term course
better general understanding of ligands as a whole/a good survey of the field, confidence in determining ligand properties, some insight into ligand design
I learned about coordination compounds, especially how to tune their properties to achieve desired effects.
Fundamentals of transition metal chemistry, electron counting, and research skills.
Transitional metal chemistry, coordination complexes, inorganic chemistry
I gained a better understanding of the characteristics of coordination complexes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Additional handout resources (e.g., scans of textbook pages relevant to the topics for students interested in going deeper in the content) would be helpful

Strengths -- Pat makes the course really engaging, worked problems on the board are super helpful and help students in the class get used to working together

Weaknesses -- Information about each topic isn't really linear, each individual day of class covered enough different topics that keeping things straight got confusing

Working at the board in small groups was helpful, but sometimes I did not feel prepared to tackle the examples based on what was said in the lecture to that point. Having an example before we do it ourselves would make it less intimidating. Also, the additional video lectures had valuable information that maybe should've had more attention in class. The ligand project was kind of difficult, especially when it had to be planned before we really learned much about ligand classes and design, and then felt rushed by the time we had enough information to work on it.

I thought the course was super well-organized to make sure everyone was on the same page! I liked the grading breakdown, it didn't make any one assignment too stressful/important. I also thought that it was well-instructed! The only weakness was if slides weren't uploaded in advance, it made it difficult to follow in lecture because the slides are so heavy on complicated diagrams and structures, but this happened only a few times!
This course emphasizes collaborative learning and rewards engagement. I believe that there could be slightly more emphasis on recent literature in transition metal chemistry.

Strengths: the course overall was very fair. The ligand project was absolutely great; I enjoyed it so much and loved getting to learn more about a topic of my choosing. Workload is pretty fair as well.
Weaknesses: The course could have benefitted from a peer tutor or TA. It was difficult having Prof. Holland as our only resource.
There aren't any weaknesses. The class had a group working segment in every lecture, which is great for improving one's skills before homework.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it's really fantastic for getting a firmer grasp of the fundamentals of inorganic chemistry and coordination chemistry and the topics in this class aren't covered at the same level in other courses

Yes! It was a great overview of ligand/transition metal complexes, covering a lot of different topics in the field. It solidifies your understanding of things you think you already know about ligands, and introduces some new concepts and considerations as well. Pat is also one of the better instructors in the department - he keeps your attention and makes the class enjoyable and accessible.

Yes! If you want to learn about coordination complexes/go into more detail than an introductory inorganic class, this is a great choice! Prof Holland is really nice and really wants you to succeed, and the final project was actually pretty fun.
Yes, this is a great course for students looking to learn more about chemistry and interact with graduate students on a daily basis.
I would recommend this course; even though it was a 400-level course, I think someone with a basic idea of the concepts before hand could do well in the class.
